transcripts.text: So Tulsi Gabbard not only won the debate, but she exposed the fact that many Democrats, though they claim to be the party of peace, are actually neocon warmongers.  So first of all, let's talk about why I think Tulsi Gabbard won the debate.  It's pretty simple.  She ended up being the most Googled candidate.  during and after the debate, which is huge when you're a candidate that is seeking name recognition.  That is the entire point of being there on the debates.  You want people to say, who are you?  I need to find out more about you.  That's the whole point.  If you're a candidate that's coming in with less name recognition than somebody like Joe Biden or Bernie Sanders or Elizabeth Warren, who have a lot more name recognition in the stage.  So Really, I think that that means I mean, she wasn't the only winner.  There's several ways to win a debate, but that is certainly a massive, massive thing.  So that was huge for her.  And I'm sure she received a bump in the fundraising.  It'll be interesting to see how much each of the candidates did receive a bump in the fundraising during and after the debates.  That would be really the true indicator of who won the debates.  is based on that, how many individual contributions they received.  Because it's not just about getting your name out there, but it's also about getting people to want to spread your message more and to donate to that.  But the big thing that Tulsi did besides that was she exposed the Democratic warmongering message by calling out Tim Ryan.  So let's watch this exchange.  Jump off what he said.

He described engagement as the problem.  The parents of those two soldiers who were just killed in Afghanistan, well, we just have to be engaged.  As a soldier, I will tell you that answer is unacceptable.

That answer is absolutely unacceptable.  When I watch that clip, I get a little emotional because we are sending off our troops into these battles like pawns and they don't sign up.  to become petro-police.  And that's really what our military is now used for.  They're out there to enforce the petrodollar, to enforce wars for oil, and that's not what these troops are signing up for.  They're signing up to serve and protect Americans, to serve and protect our country.  And yet they're just being marched around like a type of police force.  And, you know, that is what Tulsi is saying, is that that is unacceptable.  to say, well, we have to.  We have to be there.  That's why you're sacrificing your life.  We just have to be there.  So let's go on here.  She says some great things throughout this exchange.

I would just say, I don't want to be engaged.  I wish we were spending all this money in places that I've represented that have been completely forgotten and we were rebuilding.  But the reality of it is, if the United States isn't engaged, the Taliban will grow.  And they will have... Bigger, bolder terrorist acts.  We have got to have some present there.

You know, this is what they all say.  They all say this.  We have to.  I don't want to.  I'm for peace.  I don't want war.  I don't want to do this, but we have to.  And then they give a variety of bullshit reasons as to why we have to.  And for him, it's, well, if we don't, then the Taliban will spread.  The Taliban, the Taliban.  The Taliban has never come after the United States.  They've never been our enemy.  They're definitely an oppressive place.  I don't think we should be there.  I don't think they should be there in Afghanistan.  But we and Saudi Arabia and a few other nations helped create the Taliban.  We were largely responsible for the Taliban's existence to begin with.  which if you've watched some of my other videos, I explain that in detail of exactly how that happened.  But this is what all of these neocon democratic warmongers say, is they say, I don't want this.  I'm for peace, but we have to.  He gassed children.  He's a brutal dictator.  He's a monster.  Look at the way he rules his people.  They say this about everybody.  And they've continued to say this and they've continued to march us into these wars.  And it's not the truth.  That's not why we're there.  And this is the line they always, they always spread.  I don't want to, but we have to.
Taliban was there long before we came in.
They'll be there long before we leave.  We cannot keep U.S.
troops deploying to Afghanistan thinking that we're going to somehow squash this Taliban that has been there.  I didn't say squash them.  I didn't say squash them.
When we weren't in there, they started flying planes into our buildings.
So I'm just saying right now— The Taliban didn't attack us on 9-11.  Al-Qaeda did.  Al-Qaeda attacked us on 9-11.
That's why I and so many other people joined the military, to go after Al-Qaeda, not the Taliban.

The Taliban was protecting those people who were plotting against us.  All I'm saying is if we want to go in to elections and we want to say that we got to withdraw from the world, that's what President Trump is saying.  We can't.  I would love for us to.
You know who's protecting Al Qaeda right now in Saudi Arabia?

Yes.  Absolutely.  It is Saudi Arabia.  Why are we still using this excuse?  I mean, the Taliban, look, sure, after 9-11, they were maybe harboring bin Laden.  But al-Qaeda has been paid for and funded by Saudi Arabia.  Saudi Arabia has harbored and cultivated more terrorists than the Taliban.  Why aren't we going after Saudi Arabia? This is when she would go to war.
What would your red line be for military action against Iran?

Look, obviously, if there was an attack against the American, our troops, then there would have to be a response.  But my point is, and it's important for us to recognize this, is Donald Trump and his cabinet, Mike Pompeo, John Bolton, and others, are creating a situation that just a spark would light off a war with Iran, which is incredibly dangerous.  That's why we need to deescalate tensions.  Trump needs to get back into the Iran nuclear deal and swallow his pride.  Put the American people first.

Yeah, absolutely.  That is the right answer.  The red line needs to be when we are provoked.  We need to be a sleeping giant.  We need to be docile.  We need to be on our own over here, just minding our own business.  And unless someone provokes us, like what happened during Pearl Harbor for World War II, that is when we march ourselves into war. But, you know, it took a long time to get us into World War II.  It was a hard sell to the American people.  It wasn't a look.  You know, we were watching our allies being taken over by Germany.
